Award.AwardTitle: Fast Growth of Large Diamond Crystals in Open Air

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to elucidate the mechanisms responsible for growth of large diamond crystals at carat levels on non-diamond substrates in open air for industrial applications. The proposed research will establish a synthetic strategy using laser vibrational-resonant excitation in diamond growth. A gas mixture of ethylene, acetylene and oxygen will be used as precursors. Using a tunable carbon dioxide laser, vibrational resonant excitations of the alkene group of molecules will be induced to promote chemical reactions and enhance diamond growth. An excimer laser with ultraviolet wavelength will also be used to improve the quality of the diamond crystals. Deliverables include a laser system configured for fast growth of diamond crystals in air, documentation of research results, and engineering student education.

This research project will develop a simple, low-cost approach for synthesizing large diamond crystals. The research results will create a new direction for diamond growth and expand the horizon for industrial diamond uses beyond the current applications in electronics, optics, mechanical cutting and sensors, to name a few. The cost savings for diamond synthesis will be realized through the use of common hydrocarbon gases as precursors. Additionally, using this technique it is expected that many more complicated diamond crystals and devices can be realized at a much lower cost. The technique also has the promise of enabling an easy and viable route for fabricating large-scale diamond structures.

Institution.Name: University of Nebraska-Lincoln
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: BOARD OF REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF NEBRASKA

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Diamond has long been the ultimate fantasy and avid pursuit of human beings. The inimitable charm of diamond comes from its peerless beauty and a wide range of the-most-and-best properties. The hardest of all known materials, diamond exhibits the highest bulk modulus, the highest thermal conductivity at room temperature, the lowest compressibility, broad optical transparency (from the ultraviolet to the far infrared region), excellent electrical insulation, high radiation hardness, low friction, and remarkable chemical inertness. Therefore, it is not surprising that diamond is the Big Apple of eyes and an ideal material for a vast range of applications. The unbeatable charm of diamond has fueled the desire for a rich supply of superior yet affordable diamond. Unfortunately, it is not an easy job.

 

Researchers at the University of Nebraska – Lincoln (UNL) developed an open-air synthetic technique directly growing diamond on various surfaces, such as silicon and copper. By deploying resonant vibrational excitation, tremendous amount of energy (supplied by a laser) was purposefully coupled into specific molecules, ethylene, to enhance the diamond growth process. Considering an average diamond growth rate at several micrometers per hour in a typical commercial chemical vapor deposition process, a surprisingly high growth rate of 110 μm/hr was achieved in this study. In addition to diamond thin films, diamond crystals up to several millimeters were produced. According to the investigation, coupling the energy into different states of ethylene molecules would lead to obviously different results in terms of diamond growth rate, surface morphology, and diamond crystalline quality. The differences are ascribed to the fine tune of chemical species and corresponding populations in the reaction system.

 

By combining the diamond synthesis technique with ultrafast laser surface processing, the Nebraska team realized seed-free growth of diamond. Seed-free growth of diamond films on Cu enables the easy fabrication of diamond coatings on metals and corresponding metal-diamond composites for a broad range of applications like heat sink and anticorrosion. Unfortunately, it is well known that direct deposition of continuous and stable diamond films on metals is a challenging task. For metals that form stable alloys and carbides with carbon, such as Fe and Ni, carbon reacts easily with the metals at high temperatures. For metals that do not react with carbon, such as Cu, significantly different thermal expansion coefficients and weak metal-carbon interactions lead to easy-peeling diamond films. Therefore, direct deposition of diamond coatings on metals and fabrication of metal-diamond composites are very challenging. The Nebraska team deployed the ultrafast laser processing to create patterned micro- & nanoscale features on Cu before diamond deposition. It is demonstrated that the micro- & nanoscale features significantly promoting the diamond nucleation and stabilizing the diamond films.

 

Under the NSF support, five graduate students and two undergraduate students received systematic multidisciplinary training on diamond growth, material characterization, optical spectroscopic analysis, mass spectrometric analysis, and ultrafast laser processing during the project period. Multidisciplinary knowledge established in this project was distributed via teaching (ELEC 973 Introduction to Nanotechnology), undergraduate research experience programs, journal publications (11), conference presentations (12), external collaboration, and outreach activities. Due to its application values, the Nebraska team established collaboration with Department of Defense and other universities seeking more applications. As one of a few diamond research groups in the U.S.A., the Nebraska team demonstrated the leadership in this field.

 


Last Modified: 10/08/2016
Modified by: Yongfeng Lu
